reviews.comment: Please don't listen to people who complain about Gregor and CPSC 110. They say stuff like "people only like this course because they've been coding their whole lives". I had barely any coding experience coming into this course and it did not help me at all. If you put in effort, you will have fun and succeed.
MY GOAT 😍😍🐐🐐❗❗

Gregor is a warm-hearted prof. I remember one time he attended my lab and he show everyone some advice how to work on lab problems. He told me something related to the beauty of coding (?) I could not remember. Although I'm a non-cs major, I really think I picked up something from him. But Gregor talks really slow so sometimes it is pretty annoying

Gregor is a strict but caring professor. He may seem harsh sometimes but he genuinely wants you to succeed. I had no programming experience prior to this course, but if you listen to him you will most likely succeed. DO NOT fall behind because the concepts are connected. The exams are fair and relevant to the material covered. Course taken: 2023W1

People say Gregor is great because they're cs majors, and who in cs don't know coding beforehand? 110 is NOT beginner-friendly. Taking his course felt like learning how to speak a language fluently in 3 months. Students can't help each other on psets, and the learning environment  is just depressing and unhealthy. Pls avoid if it's not a major req.
He's rather strict and a little bit difficult, but overall a pretty good prof. As long as you study you should be fine. Not very approachable, but a good prof overall.

He is super caring and very intelligent.

Advice for his class:
- Focus, his content can be hard, but very enjoyable
- Do the homework, go to lectures, and practice problem sets over and over.
- This course is easy if you put in about 16 hours a week and you will have a great time!
-Trust the natural recursion.

The prof spends a lot of time "complaining" about how there are sooo many students to manage, and how its soo hard. Yet the course slides and course itself is riddled with mistakes, typos, and errors (so many errors everywhere). Also, this is not an intro course. It's way too fast-paced and heavy, especially if you have no previous experience (me)
He has done this for a long time, and it really shows.

Amazing prof! CPSC 110 is a very fun course and completely doable. Just make sure to keep up with the edX content, pay attention to all lectures, finish all problem sets on time, and grind the past midterms / finals. Oh, and make sure to come to a lot of office hours.

Gregor came off as intimidating at first, but you soon realize that's just his humour. He's extremely helpful during office hours, walking around to check in on every student and how they're doing. If you don't fully understand the content, make sure to stay on top of all the work.

Gregor has so much personality. I did find him condescending at first (I never asked questions in lecture), but I grew to appreciate his sense of humour over time. This course requires lots of time and effort, but solving the problems is so incredibly rewarding. I also felt that he truly cared about his students and wanted us to succeed.
The course isn't too difficult as long as you don't fall too behind. Rewatching lecture recordings helps a lot with understanding the content.

Great lectures, however you must pay immense attention to be able to do good. A lot of practice required. The course load is very heavy, even unfair at times - but is very rewarding and has a lot of learning outcome. Gregor was very supportive and answered most questions as best as possible in a 600 student class.

Hated to answer student questions unless they were "good enough" and was completely unhelpful when students faced online issues (there were a ton of technical issues). Overly anal about the details and lectures were monotone, slow, and boring. You're better off watching lecture recordings at 2x speed than attending class. Definitely overrated

Gregor was a fun prof. Attending lectures is essential and make sure you actually listen when he says to try the problems in the videos on your own instead of just following along. He was a fair teacher and funny. Only problem is the course is hard but if you genuinely do all the problems and not just follow along in the video you will be fine
he is good professor, and made our first year fantastic
well, i would say greogr himself is a very conscientious prof who wants you to be successful in the class, nonetheless the course itself is very very poorly designed in my opinion

DO NOT think you can get away from this course without putting in the amount of work the Prof said clearly at the beginning of the class. Your whole pyramid scheme of knowledge will fall apart just by missing one part of the course. Also, do what the course tells you to, don't act smart

Gregor is a nice guy, no doubt of that. From my experience and my friend's, he's kind and helpful when you see him during office hours. However, during our online lectures, he seems to be the opposite, and that's, unfortunately, where we learn from him most of the time. Furthermore, I'm not a fan of the way he teaches, as I leave lectures confused.

Passive-aggressiveness makes me more uncomfortable to ask questions in a 600 ppl lecture. Even though there's 1300 students in the course, it's hard to find a peer to help you with problem sets. It's either you go through a torturous process of figuring it out yourself, find a friend to take the course with you and do them together, or fail them.
was a cool prof, but the tests are pretty hard for a student never coded before(me). ;( and I don't found tat hybrid lectures are helpful...

Gregor is a fair professor and you can tell he wants his students to succeed. However, he can sometimes come off as passive-aggressive which can discourage students from participating and asking questions. Regardless, he is a good prof and I would love to take a class with him again.

He was very engaging during our online lectures, and he made each lecture memorable and enjoyable by playing music before lecture and adding jokes and catchphrases to material. His class has a lot of prework (probably another 3-6hrs per week), but I believe if you pay attention during class, you will do great.
It's a challenging course, but Gregor does his best to makes sure everyone suceeds.

Gregor the goat. The course is fast paced so it's difficult to catch up if you fall behind. It's clear that Gregor cares about student experience and fairness as he gives great compensation for unfairness. Gregor takes great care in designing the course and office hours are helpful. There wasn't any scaling :). Trust the recursion!
Everybody loves gregor, hes a great prof, very caring about his students.

If you want a prof that cares about his students, GREGOR IS THE GOAT. You will see so many memes about him but if you pay attention, listen to his advice. Actually do work. You will do good trust me. This course is all about, "if you understand the material, you will get it". He has so many resources too.

CPSC 110 covered A LOT of material over the span of three months, including question that are considered "hard" on leetcode. Gregor is a very nice and calm person, and he really explained the concepts well. Unfortunate that he hasn't been teaching anything else at UBC for the past few years. Make sure to trust the natural recursion!
Test heavy, intense lectures, if you fall behind it is impossible to catch up. Also if you are a beginner to CS, NEVER EVER take this course, your last bit of interest will be GONE.
Not reasonable grading criteria of this course, but it is a compulsory course for so many major requirement, student is easy to fail this course by performing badly in final
Hard but good course.

Incredibly beginner unfriendly, super overrated imo. A prof especially at UBC should understand that not every student learns from a specific learning/teaching method. If you are unlucky and don't understand him and his way of teaching your chances of being successful are not that high. Some ppl love him, but I didn't have the same experience.

Gregor is a great prof, but the course itself is super hard. It should be split across at least 2 terms, and preferable 2 courses (CPSC103 CPSC107 is still not sufficient). It is not beginner friendly, would suggest to stay in 2-3 days advance of the course.

CPSC 110 is a tough course with some pretty serious content. This course moves FAST, if you're not willing to put in the work, you will fail. Gregor is a great guy and obviously really does care about this course and his students, however, sometimes he comes off as a bit too intense and it makes it hard to enjoy this course.

Gregor is one of the best profs I've ever had. His lectures are incredibly informative and you will learn a ton from him. His question answering style takes a bit to get used to, but once you're accustomed he can be extremely funny. Gregor gives great advice about the course and his teachings truly help you exceed in 110.
Gregor was awesome, It is very clear that he cares about improving the course and the growth of his students, he is very avalable outside of class and pushes you to get better at computer science
He is the most overrated prof at UBC. CPSC110 is extremely unfriendly to first year students: too difficult, too much content, it wastes you a lot of time on meaningless data design.

This guy dropped out of mit eecs undergrad, I don't think I've ever met an actual genius like him in my life (including other profs, etc). Dude's an amazing prof, and I don't say that much. IQ would probably be over 160 if I had to guess. Also don't mind the low ratings from this semester cause like half the class got caught cheating lol

Maybe I'd rate him higher if it wasn't CPSC 110, but Gregor made decisions around the course (Specifically the choice of programming language) that I highly disagree with. This was the one course that almost made me hate computer science, and when I took CPSC 210/221 I found it to be a far better experience. So clearly something is wrong.
Gregor is a great professor! He goes through concepts clearly and makes it very clear what steps you should take if you want to succeed in this course.

I was not a huge fan of CPSC110, but Gregor generally seemed like a good guy. He is very adamant about his perspectives regarding software development and can seem arrogant sometimes; however, he definitely cares for his students and is passionate about the course.
Dr. Gregor has insane rizz

Honestly, I don't get the hype around Gregor. I personally don't feel like the way he teaches really helps you learn until a few lectures later where you understand why he explained everything in a beating around the bush way. The lectures are also rushed because they are just recaps of the online modules in about an hour. I'd take Ola's section.

Gregor is the best professor I have ever had. You can tell he genuinely loves what he does and he cares for his students. His office hours are also incredibly useful. I wish Gregor taught higher level courses as I would definitely take him again. I highly recommend. As long as you keep up with the work and practice, you will get a good grade.

Gregor is an amazing prof who cares about his students and guides them through the difficult course content. He emphasizes the importance of struggling when learning so do be prepared to struggle, but there are plenty of resources available. His lectures are fast-paced so I would recommend making sure to do the pre-lecture work on edX.
Never coded before taking this class, but his lectures made everything easy to understand! Would highly recommend.

Gregor is a respected professor with profound knowledge. Note that the language Dr. Racket would be brought up again in 121 and 210 where most theoretical/practical components start to emerge. So, don't underestimate the importance of the class. Gregor also teaches you how to think like a software engineer(aka block-level thinking). Don't miss out!
The natural recursion has saved me

Difficult class- you get what you put in. Gregor is not very understanding of students in his office hours and I found him to be extremely condescending. Additionally, the assignments are nitpicky, the course content is outdated and not very relevant.

Gregor is a wonderful lecturer and he is extremely passionate. I love this course so so much. However, many people complain that its too dense and fast-paced. An understanding computer science specifically is helpful but nonecessary. If you want to succeed in 110, you must trust the recipes they give you and apply it the way they want you to

Great professor, very clear delivery and the course is laid out well, clearly well thought out. Often stressed for time during lecture so can come off as a bit snappy but is nice if you're asking a relevant question

Super passionate and easily one of the best profs! Gregor always encourages students to ask questions and he explains things clearly in lectures, office hours, edX videos, & Piazza.

I suggest watching edX videos before class and rewatching lectures; note that it is homework heavy. You can understand 110 if you put effort and aren't behind. Great!

Passionate about what he's doing. The course is difficult and the lectures go fast as there is a lot of content, however he always tries to leave time for students to understand and stops to take questions multiple times per lecture. Lots of office hours which are helpful. Overall a very enjoyable experience.

The lectures were often rushed and Gregor tended to assume we knew more than we actually do, skipping over basic concepts and leaving most people in the dust, even those who stayed on top of readings and everything. Other prof (Ola) would recap what we learned at the end of each lecture which really helped, so I would recommend her more.
He funny

Gregor is really invested in his students' learning and I could feel that even as an online student. He always encourages students to ask questions and he explains things pretty clearly in his lectures, office hours, edX videos, and Piazza. His course is structured in a way that it's not very hard to understand if you put in the effort.
Passionate. Organized. Fair. Kind.

Clearly very passionate about what he does and knows exactly what he's talking about in every single lecture. Honestly one of the brightest people I've ever been able to learn from. 10/10 would recommend if you're willing to put in the work
Truly an amazing professor. Super knowledgeable and caring for his students.

Gregor is easily my favourite instructor I've had for any course, ever. His teaching style is engaging, he's clearly extremely knowledgeable about the content, and he's a genuinely amazing person. I'd totally recommend him to literally anyone.

Gregor is a very straightforward professor that runs a very efficient and information-dense style of lecture. Some struggled with the pacing, but in my opinion it was completely fine if you were caught up on the coursework. Gregor doesn't hold your hand along the way, but he gives you everything you need to know in a clear and understandable format

Work is sometimes required outside of class to keep up (such as watching his edX), but Gregor is a great instructor nonetheless. Very respected and knowledgeable in his field, hard to ask for a better professor. Course content is also useful and applicable.
Shines in the EDx videos but is so intense on pedagogy that he gives you nonanswers and beats around the bush during lecture and office hours. Try to get into Ola's section instead.
the most worse prof at UBC, what he taught is useless in your CS life
Dont take him, take DR. K she is the goat, this guyz is just an old man speaking random things and wont even answer ur questions, very arrogant and disturbing ur brain person. just don't take him
the most worse professor I have ever seen in my life

Great on EDx where Gregor shines. However, his lectures are way too packed, there is way too much going on to follow. He literally has to rush his last words to fit it all in 90 mins. Constantly states "I gotta move on!". Assumes his entire class is doing well despite the same 10 people asking questions. Seems frustrated for no reason.

It's been this bad since 2013 based on comments
Instead of grading your work himself there is this badly coded autograder that will frustrate you to no end
Course uses DrRacket which is just the worst programming lang ever afaik
He can't even teach all the material in lecture time because there's so much
Takes as much as 3 4-credit courses no joke

Had him for 2021W1. He seemed scary at first but trust me, he's actually just very passionate and cares a lot about the content he delivers! This course takes a lot of hard work and grind, but Gregor teaches VERY well during lectures and always encourages you to do work outside of lectures because you should!! No programming exp needed. :)
sometimes explains thinks too technically, wish he'd make analogies, or break down concepts a bit simpler but other than that great prof
Absolute legend and very knowledgeable about CS education and working in industry. Also super accessible outside of class. Take his lecture section, it's a no-brainer! :)
Trust the natural recursion

a very respected professor. Hops straight on the point in the lectures and every minute is informative. If you only pay attention in classes and invest 2 hrs outside of class every day, you are easily acing his class. Is a tough grader in exams. Just follow his methods and everything will be good. Follow the recipe : xD

If you are looking for a nice grade in this class, please please do not take this professor's section. Even though he is a very respected professor, his exams are harsh and you will end up spending almost your entire time on this course.

Greg may seems like a very tough professor when you first started CPSC110, but he got some softness inside trust me. He is a smart and excellent in CS. I could see that a lot of his opinions and lecturing were actually really helpful if you want to enter this field.

prof gregor genuinely wants you to learn and every activity is his lecture is designed towards that aim. super caring, sometimes he makes jokes and be close to students. only thing is sometimes its hard to hear him (or my listening is just bad) and he has this lullaby melodic voice that makes u want to sleep. but i love him!

This class was a LOT of work, and it's super important to make sure you keep up, as it is exponentially harder to catch up once the week has passed. Gregor seemed generally empathetic to students and would offer encouragement often, but he struck me as somewhat unapproachable to talk to one-on-one during office hours/ after lecture.

This class is extremely hard a definitely a lot of work, however, professor Kiczales always encouraged us to keep trying and was always available weekly to answer any questions. His lectures were extremely helpful though sometimes hard to follow along if you are behind. All in all, he was a great prof and definitely recommend this class with him.

A well-respected prof, also the guy in the EdX videos. He obviously knows what he's doing so you should take him if a lecture seat is available. That being said, the material in CPSC110 is quite challenging so extra work outside of class is required.

Putting aside the memes, Professor Kiczales is genuinely a good professor. He is understanding and very active on our class forum, Piazza. For myself, his lectures were engaging and often funny. Do not be shy to participate in "pass or play" during lectures. One word of warning for the course: beware of problem set 9, do not procrastinate. Glhf! :)

Gregor Kiczales is an absolute legend at UBC. It was a pleasure to be taught by him. This course has a lot of homework but if you work hard and pay attention in lectures, you can get a great grade in this class. This course will completely change the way you approach programming, so even if you have experience, pay full attention.
Amazing prof- attend his office hours, he genuinely cares so much for you. Great jokes. Challenging course but he pushes us through.
Great course
If there's a seat left in Gregor's lecture section, take it. Don't think. Just do. He created the course, he knows what students need to do in order to succeed. Just take him.

Brilliant, evidence-based course design. The most demanding university course I've ever taken, but probably the most valuable and definitely an all-time favorite. As a lecturer he is pretty good I guess? But his biggest strength is caring about students. If you're struggling with anything inside OR outside class, he will listen and he will help!

Can be a bit harsh in lectures, but does want the best for you to learn. Would take this class again in a heartbeat but it was much more time consuming than any of my other classes. Although it was the most time consuming it was also my favorite class.
he obviously does not know how to respect students very rude sometimes. his videos are good tho
Good course. Gotta try hard though
Excellent and kind prof

Gregor's an amazing professor, he has great humor which makes his lectures much more engaging and fun. Every year after each term there's always the CPSC 110 memes about Gregor. Overall an amazing professor, accessible outside of class, kind, and humorous.
Gem of a person. Truly showed us he cares about all his students, despite the ginormous class strength.
Great prof! Explained concepts very well. This is a tough class but he was a good teacher.
Only 20% of lecture is related to useful knowledge that help understanding. Rest of time Gregor talks too much craps.
CPSC hurts your brain so its nice to have a really good teacher like Gregor.
Course structure is fine but why are lecture quizzes worth so much. I get that he's trying to help us to catch up but making them 15% of our grade is just stressful.
Absolutely amazing prof, never had someone as respected and passionate teaching

Gregor was an amazing prof! His lectures were very engaging with clicker questions and lots of voluntary student participation. CPSC 110 was well organized and never left me with a feeling of uncertainty that I felt in some other courses (like MATH 100). I worried a lot about the 15% weigh in clicker questions but he was very lenient in the end.
Gregor is amazing. Very smart and caring. I always looked forward to lectures, and this course made me want to major in CS.

The entirety of the 110 teaching staff and TA's deserve so much respect. They were so understanding of the stress level this term and modified the course to make it as manageable as possible. The EdX videos are so helpful and every single thing we do in the course is useful. Gregor is one of the most caring professors, and makes cpsc110 awesome

CPSC 110 is the best organized course I've ever taken, and Gregor clearly knows his stuff when it comes to delivering this course. He's funny and knows what students will find difficult and how to best approach the material from many years of experience. Can't go wrong with choosing him for this prolific intro course.
Gregor is a true master of his craft, and is also quite talented at teaching his craft to others. UBC is lucky to have him, and Im glad I was able to take a course with him.

Gregor is definitely very professional in the course materials and structures the course very well with everything to be expected outlined very clearly. He could be intimidating by throwing questions back at you at times, but he is actually very caring for his students. His office hours are plenty and very helpful. A solid choice for CPSC110.
Gregor is a great prof and his lectures are very informative. The course itself is very, very challenging in terms of workload, but tests are fair. Trust the natural recursion and you'll be fine.
CPSC110 is the most well-organized course I have taken. It inspired me to pursue a minor in computer science.

Gregor is the best professor. He gives amazing lectures, is always super clear and takes many questions. But most importantly, he does what is best for his students. He reduced the course load and made grading more lenient due to the difficulties of online learning and acknowledges that everyone is tired! Hands down best prof!
Lots of work and practice, but it pays off.
Absolute gem and genius, like he's so knowledgable and good in the subject matter but at the same time CPSC 110 ain't no joking matter I would grind it out.

I had Kiczales for 110. He's one of those cases of a very strong teacher who is also extraordinarily intelligent. He has developed a strategy for teaching computer science to beginners that works very well. All you have to do to succeed in his class is listen to the suggestions given. His lectures make sure to show you real world applications.
This class is just a mass. So as the prof and TA

Gregor is awesome! He may seem strict at first, but you quickly realize that he wants the best for his students, and that he is passionate about teaching CS to first year students. Quite possibly the best course I have taken to date at this University. As a bonus, he sometimes shares the memes made about him on the ubc subreddit. An amazing prof!

He's a good professor who definitely knows what he's doing. I didn't particularly like or dislike him. CPSC 110 is a grind and there is always so much work to do but the course itself is not very difficult at all.

He is very caring and does his best for you to learn, but the course is very hard especially if you have never done coding before. If you miss a lecture, you fall behind quite a lot and will not understand anything next lecture if you don't catch up. Also you have to do a lot of work outside class like problem sets and pre-lecture videos. Gregor <3
Exam was tough but his teaching style is nice and easily understandable.
Gregor really cares about his students and the course is very well organized.

Theres not much to be said that hasnt already preceded Gregor by memes or reputation. He created CPSC 110 and is extremely knowledgeable in the subject matters he teachers, he's charismatic and engaging and he consistently challenges his students to become better thinkers and problem solvers. If you're taking CPSC 110 Gregor is the only way to go.

The best teacher ever! CPSC 110 was an amazing experience with Gregor. He is super knowledgeable and caring. The course is quite hard, but definitely doable if you work hard throughout the term, and Gregor offers a lot of support with office hours and videos to stay caught up. You need to take 110, it's awesome!

Gregor is definitely one of the best profs I've ever seen. He might seem very strict at first but know that he is always ready to help and gives constructive feedback. Never miss the chance to take CPSC110 with him. The course material might feel hard or time-consuming but he knows this. His attitude towards the subject made me want to TA with him.

Strict but amazing prof. Comp sci is hard but he does his best to teach his students. I took the online section but I met him in person as well because he was interested in feedback to improve the course. Tbh all the CPSC110 profs are great, you can't miss.
I took the online section. do NOT take the online section if you have no previous knowledge on computer science failed the online section, retaking it this term. Attending lectures really helps.

Gregor is the most amazing prof i've ever had! So inspiring and motivating. He truly cares about his students and does everything he possibly can to help them do well in his course. He is super aware of the difficulty of this course's content and never makes his students feel dumb or that they aren't capable of doing well. Overall amazing person

If you didnt choose Gregor as your CPSC 110 prof, what are you doing with your life? Best prof hands down. Teaches amazingly well, encourages students, cares for students, and teaches amazingly well. This was my first time learning programming, and I really enjoyed it. Trust the Natural Recursion. - the new motto of my life.

CPSC 110 is a beginner-friendly course, but is very fast-paced. You MUST keep up with the video lectures and problem sets. If you fall behind, you will be in trouble. If you keep up, this course is straight-forward and its really easy to do well. Gregor's video lectures explain concepts very well and he is very helpful on the discussion forums.

Gregor is hilarious and teaches the material very well and reinforces them by giving clicker quizzes at the start of every lecture. The overall course isn't very challenging but that is only if you keep up with the video lectures and practice problems. He is also hilarious and inspiring, highly recommend.

Gregor makes this tough course slightly easier, as his lectures are very straightforward and understandable. He sometimes assumes that his students know more than they actually do, based on a couple of questions asked by the same few keepers in the crowd. Make sure you keep up with the homework, especially if you have no prior experience.

Possibly the most intelligent man I've ever been taught by, but he doesn't make you feel dumb. If anything, he teaches the course in a way that makes you feel accomplished in what is being taught. The course is quite (nee very) difficult, but keeping up with EdgeX videos and attending lectures will keep your head above water. Inspiring prof.

Gregor is one of the best prof I met in UBC. He might look serious but he is super approachable and patient outside class. I am not in his section but I sometimes go to his office hours. He explains everything in a super clear efficient and encouraging way. 110 is a hard course but Gregor and his videos make everything better.

Gregor doesn't baby his students, but if you keep up with the material and stay present during lecture, you stand to gain a lot from his courses. I've seen students complain that the systematic design patterns are too rigid, but I think that they've missed the point of the material: to avoid reinventing the wheel and focus on interesting problems.
Incredibly inspiring and knowledgeable prof. If you put the work in, you will learn so much. The material is easy, there's just a loooot of it.

great prof, he knows his stuff, great at teaching the concepts, you just need to be ready to learn and want to learn, the concepts are hard and challenging but the class is fun and they always try to help your grade go up, trust me.

I really liked the beginning of the course, i never had coding experience but i was doing well. That was until the "design recipes" came in. These recipes are supposed to make coding easier. I had to follow this strict formula, which just essentially makes you have to think less, it limits any outside thinking on how to attack a problem.
He is good. Just a bit too mechanical in they way he goes about his things. Make sure you do the pre-lecture stuff or you will not get a word he teaches in lecture.
very nice and caring.

I loved CPSC 110 and I found Gregor to be an amazing prof. He is understanding of the difficulty of the course and he is an amazing lecturer. He has an amazing understanding of the course material and he always puts in the effort to make the class feel more personal despite the large size (300+).
CPSC110 was my favorite course of the term. It was well thought out, and the prof motivated me to work hard throughout.

Gregor is an amazing prof, one of the best I've had in my two years at UBC. He really cares about the learning of his students and stops often in lecture to field questions, answering them thoroughly. This class has an insane workload, but that being said, if you're willing to work hard it's very possible to get a great mark.
Great course and great professor!He cares about what he is teaching, and we wrote some great programs during this course.

This course only becomes difficult if you fall behind - this course has a huge workload! - otherwise the material is rather straightforward and relatively easy to grasp. With that said, Gregor knows this course inside and out, is extremely knowledgable, and really cares that students learn both effectively and efficiently. Great prof!

Gregor is a god level prof and should be treated as such. His lectures are fun and packed with information. He makes you work for this course, and youre gonna have to spend time on it, but if you trust the natural recursion all will be well.

Great prof, pretty much people who do well rate high and people who fail rate low. Watch your videos and practice because you will fail if you dont. The difficulty of the course is irrelevant to Gregor as a professor, and you need to spend time or else you will not do well.
Very intense course. Be prepared to devote a few hours a night to the material if you want to do well.
If you trust the natural recursion you will ace this class

Especially if you haven't programmed before, you need to be 100% on top of the homework and reading/video material. Start on assignments early. The lectures fill in the gaps with concrete examples and walk-throughs and Gregor is tough but fair. Exams were pretty reasonable.

CPSC 110 is way too condensed. This course should have splitted up into at least 3 courses. Also, doing algorithm and data structures in Racket is so inappropriate. Gregor is not a good lecturer, but his video's explanations are fine. The video is the only thing I appreciate in this course.

He's obviously a genius, but his lectures aren't helpful at all, especially if you have never done coding before (he does insist though that this class is designed for a student's first experience with programming...) I ended up going to another section's lecture for the rest of the term... btw the final was brutal, but the scaling  saved us
As long as you keep up with the videos and do your practice, his teaching really drives you to learn
best prof ever... hard and time consuming course but definitely worth it
If you fall back you're doomed. I messed up my first midterm because of this. Keep practicing and solving the problem bank.

Gregor is a professor who clearly knows every inch of the content that he teaches, and will answer questions clearly and concisely. He strives to get his students to succeed; he even stated once that "There is about $300000 worth of tuition in this room and I'm gonna make every penny count." Be warned: ton of work is involved in his courses.
I can't wait to be done with CPSC 110 with GREGOR!

An extraordinarily disappointing intro to Computer Science. Focuses on solving problems with formulaic, inflexible design patterns, graded on whether or not Gregor likes the style of your code, not whether it works or not. Gregor does his best to discourage creativity in any way possible. Future CPSC courses are much better, don't lose hope.
He is a great lecturer. His classes were very interesting. However he is arrogant and rude. I would give him a perfect 5 if it wasn't for his rudeness.
confused about the earlier commentators..  he's a great, funny, and engaging prof! enjoy while you can!
Clear teacher, very interesting lessons. I would say he is a good prof but there is A LOT of work involved with the course.
Really good prof. Lectures were engaging and interesting, and I learned new thing every class.  The course was a lot of work and sometimes he answered too many stupid questions from people.

Dr. Kiczales is the one who designed the entire course (CPSC 110) so he knows the material extremely well and answers student questions with 100% clarity. Attend lectures as he gives good problems to try. Watching the videos is a must as you will be lost if you don't. Expect to put in more time at the beginning of term if you have never programmed.

Prof. Kiczales teaches the ideas universally used in CS. Some topics are harder to grasp and you may end up spending more time on homework than you'd expected. However, the online lectures and plenty of TA hours are there to help. Just open your mind & expect mood swings from "HAHA, I'm a mighty god!!" to "Never will touch programming again!!!"

Absolutely incredible professor who distills a challenging subject matter into very clear expectations. At times, I thought he focused too heavily on some of the really obnoxious/ridiculous/unprepared student questions in lecture. The tests weren't very fair in that the marking was very, very nitpicky.
Very enthusiastic and fun! Be careful about raising your hand when he polls the class, cause he encourages participation and might call on you!

GO TO LECTURES! Skipping a month worth of lectures was the biggest mistake I've ever made in uni, 1) because I didn't learn the material properly and 2) because Gregor is actually an AMAZING prof. He is HILARIOUS & knowledgable, but make sure to know your stuff because he walks around and checks on your progress, lol. And yeah, expect a LOT of work

I understand why some may be discouraged by Gregor's style, but I can guarantee that in all my years at UBC I haven't met another prof who knew their teaching material as well as Gregor did his. Pay attention and ask questions - He will find the way to help.  Also, if you mistake his personality for malice, you probably need to lighten up a bit.

I absolutely love Gregor's personality and teaching methodologies. I think this course was the best way for me to be introduced to programming, and it really boosted my confidence in my own abilities to code. He thinks so far ahead and really understands what is best for the students. But don't expect it to be easy, pay attention to lectures.
I'm pretty sure the negative responses to Gregor were before my time. Easy A, super helpful, nothing could be negative

I wanted to major in CPSC before taking 110. After 110, I never wanted to take CPSC again. I gave it one more shot and took 210 after. Holy cow, if you are even remotely interested in CPSC but himhis class dissuades you, give it one more shot! His class is ridiculous and a poor "introduction" into CPSC. Every other CPSC class is amazing.
Horrible prof

I found 110 to be a great intro class; yes, you will use Racket which is not a widely used language, but the purpose of it is to help you learn computer scienceprogramming concepts. Be prepared to put a lot of time into this course if you want to do well. Gregor is a great teacher and is very helpful in his office hours.
Coursera videos are really detailed and helpful for learning the concepts. The final exam was much harder than the midterms.

The concept of this course is helpful for students new to programming, though still tough for rookies and requires tremendous time investment. The progress is slow for experienced programmers. More emphasis during the course is on format, readability rather than functionality. Recommended if you have time, interest, and requires a introduction.

There's certain people that have an immaculate ability to make you lose all passion and interest in a subject and Gregor does this with amazing efficiency.  The course is demanding, the teaching method is strict with little freedom of technique and completely uninspiring for anyone considering to go into programming. Avoid if possible.

The course itself is terrible frankly put (at least for someone who has done significant programming prior). Objectively, however, Kiczales is a decent professor. He teaches well, but has little respect for students (understandable since most students in this intro course don't respect his field), and very clearly has favourite students.

If you are not into computer science or you are very bad at thinking mathematically, you should not take CPSC 110. Computer science is not for everyone. That being said, Kiczales tends to be an otherwise average prof, though you should expect to work hard to do well in this course. Be prepared from day 1 to watch ALL videos and practice thoroughly

Extremely rude. If you catch him on a mistake he will change his original question and try to make you look like an idiot in front of the entire class. Will kick you out if he sees you whispering to a neighbor. Expects you to watch hours worth of videos featuring him after each class. Based in BSL, you will never use this language out of class.

This course uses a language which is not used anywhere outside this class. It is extremely frustrating if you get stuck because it's hard to find help online due to this. Assignments are insanely hard if you are not perfectly adept with the material. Labs are quite difficult too. I took 210 after and this course is in no way an "intro". AVOID!
Great prof/personality

Everyone here is complaining how the course was ridiculous and unclear. Although the course was VERY time consuming and stressful at times, Gregor did well at explaining and the in-class problems helped a lot. If you paid attention to the problems he was doing in class, it's easy. Videos were very helpful but needs better explanation in lectures.

I feel that this course has been made too difficult to be considered a "beginner" 4 credit course. The videos we watch online are easy to understand, however if you have a heavy-ish course load... DON'T TAKE CPSC110. Spare yourself from that. This course requires ~15hours of DEDICATED TIME PER WEEK. If cpsc110 is req, then take it. OTHERWISE DON'T!

I hated computer science before this class. I took it years back and failed and now I have to come back to it. He lighted up the interest again. Exams are hard .. ish but if you have really done your exercises, you will at least get a B-. I missed many assignments but still managed well. Overall a fun experience.

Really clear teaching, but the volume of material in the course was astronomical, even by standards of a four-credit course. Also lots of video-watching required. If you aren't already taking fifteen other credits, take this course, I guess! But prepare to work very hard, or suffer for not doing so. It's not a pleasant course at all.

Great prof. Very clear and good at teaching. Lectures were an extension of online vids so if you missed a class it usualy wasnt a big deal. Grading is clear cut; like math, you get it or you dont. Many ppl took this as a easy course. They didnt understand basic concepts and wrongly blamed gregor. That is why everyone here from 110 seems to hate him
The most ridiculous course ever

He made the final a very big programming and divided it into 3 parts. When finish Part A on your own pace, you submit A and get B. After B you had a choice on C1(hard) or C2(easy but 10 marks deducted). Switching took long and you can't switch back. Days after the final he started to check plagiarism on our previous homework. Interesting.

DON'T taking this course unless this is a requirement for your further courses. It took unimaginable amount of time to prep before a lecture and digest after, and to complete the problem sets, projects and labs. Basically you study all the material by watching videos. Lectures barely gave new info but added one more practice problem every time.

This course was a load of bull. He expects you to watch a bunch of videos of him teaching online, so he can just confuse you more in lectures. Kiczales should really reevaluate his course design: teach us in lecture and let us practice at home. Not all of us can be self-taught. I thought he would know better as a CS department head.

Kiczales expects you to spend 4 hours each day to watch free online videos and teach ourselves. Gregor, some of us have part-time jobs and full courseload. It would be fair for us to allocate practice time ourselves, but to teach ourselves!? Are you kidding me? This course is a joke, take it with another instructor who actually cares about teaching

Never have I felt as inadequate as I have when I took this class. Every single lecture was an exercise in patience as I sought not to break my laptop in frustration as Gregor sped through the course material, aided by only a couple keen students. This class ate up too much of my time. Never taking a class with Gregor again. Would not recommend.
Whatever you heard about this course after 2013 fall term is true. The course is not clear and does not make sense at all. Unless it is a requirement, do not take this course.
As others have said, this course is fast-paced and VERY time-consuming. I took this course just for fun and kinda regret it.

There's a ridiculous amount of work to do outside of lectures, most of it being prep work, and as a result the lecture feels incredibly rushed since we're expected to know everything beforehand. I highly advise that you don't take this course if you don't have your own laptop; I don't have one and I'm falling behind because of that.

Call your psychiatrist because you are about to become suicidal from this course. 110 requires as much time as all 4 of my courses combined. Gregor expects you to understand the material before coming to class and moves at an absurdly rapid pace. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS OR AFFILIATE WITH GREGOR.

Turn around and run. Prepare to watch hours of videos between each lecture and going to lecture where he assumes you understand everything while he moves onto the next topic. Prepare to spend 10+ hours working on problem sets every week and pull a 5/10 (the average usually stands around there). Exams are coding entire programs, pencil and paper.

It probably used to be a great course until this sem. Its a pain thinking going to class if you don't have a laptop. The assignments are not clear and it seems like the material is extremely rushed; no time to fully absorb and appreciate what is being learned. Course is advertised as beginner but it's very far from. Not for the light hearted. RUN!

I really liked programming before taking Gregors course, but I slowly found myself being drained of all interest as the course became work and not fun. With lectures and lab included you will spend 9-10 hours a week on the course, leaving little time for your other courses. DO NOT TAKE GREGORS COURSE!

Gregor is a nice guy, however the way he teaches the course is flawed. He doesnt teach much in lectures and instead has you watch around 1 hour or more of instructional video BETWEEN EACH LECTURE. He assigns mandatory problem sets each week which take around 1:30 each and generally reserves any instruction for self learning at home.
He is not clear and the classes are difficult and hard to understand

One of my favourite profs so far, he's very clear about what he expects of his students and his teaching is very clear. Attend lecture, do practice problems, watch the videos, etc. and it'll be an easy A/B.

I came into the class with a fair bit of programming knowledge, and I found it quite easy. At first I didn't like his teaching style too much, but at some point I think the 'template' system pays off, at least in complicated programs. It seems like he was very involved in the creation of the curriculum, and he's certainly very knowledgeable.
BEST PROF. EASY TO UNDERSTAND. NO NEED TO READ TEXTBOOKS AT ALL. EASY EXAMS.

READ THIS CAREFULLY...Gregor is an amzing prof and he designed the whole intro to CPSC course so, you couldn't get better BUT (and read this carefully) watch and read everything 'pre-lecture', do every single weekly practice problem,and GO TO THE LABS. I slacked off early and fell behind quick. He designed the sylabus, all you have to is follow it!

Heres the thing with cpsc, you MUST go to lectures and DO THE PRACTICE PROBLEMS!! If you do that, then this course is actually very easy. However, if you don't , you might actually fail. I got a B+ in this course, and i am in Arts. This prof is by far the best prof I have ever met. If you really want to learn com sci, take him.
Very passionate and clear professor who really cares about his students. I had fun in class even though originaly I took it as a science requirement. Very much recomended.

Awesome prof but you really have to pay attention and ask any doubts you have in class! He legit cares about the class doing well, lectures are detailed, but can be a bit fast paced. If you go to DLC hours and office hours, you should be good to go.
Great careful professor.  Knows his stuff well and very willing to help.  Super clear in the concept he teaches.  Very passionate about CPSC.

Gregor was the best professor. 110 was my trial course to see if I wanted to go into computer science. He invented the course. Had I not had gregor and this fantastic course I might not feel the same. He expects you to work, but he is very fair in how the course is marked. I would take this with Gregor for anyone considering cpsc as a degree.

The course isn't easy. The expectations and effort you need to put in are outlined explicitly. If you do it- you will do fine. Gregor is simply amazing. He puts in so much effot into this course and explain things in a clear manner. He is a truly caring and dedicated prof. I'd take 110 again just to have him as a prof.
A great prof with very clear and intuitive exposition of the material. Absolutely perfect for an intro to compsci course.

Great prof and great class. unlike a previous commenter, I am an arts student with no experience and got an 80 in the class. very fair marking and really interesting and helpful. Highly recommended if you're interested.

Incredible Prof. ATTEND HIS LECTURES. The course itself isn't easy, but with his clarity and his ability to explain EVERYTHING, he makes the class worth it! Genuinely interesting and my favorite prof so far...

He may be a nice, funny guy, but as an arts student taking the class for fun (with no experience) it would have taken 4+h/week of going in to get help to get a decent grade, not worth the trouble!  Lectures were him and top students in the class chatting about advanced problems.  No good for beginners/the casually interested!

Really good prof! His lectures are clear and well organized. The course itself isn't a free ride, it's work, but if you stay on top of the problem sets its super rewarding! I bet the people who didn't like him fell behind and discouraged themsleves: nothing wrong with Gregor himself.
EXCELLENT prof!! His lectures are well-organized and engaging and he is very helpful during office hours.
AMAZING PROF!! Go see him during office hours, he is so wonderfully helpful and always willing to help students and offer words of encouragement. He is one of the best at UBC.
Never had a problem understanding what has been in the lectures has been a great experience so far.

Horrible professor. Literally made you do all the reading yourself. Would explain things for 15 minutes, only to tell you that we don't need to know it and it was just for interest. Makes you feel stupid in your labs when he pops in. Dropped this course because I couldn't stand him.
Great Teacher, best teacher I've had so far at UBC. Extremely helpful, he knows your name and wants you to succeed.
please drop cpsc311, dont be stupid!u will die
No Comments
Not bad I guess, Aspects were a bit hard, but doable.  Learned quite a bit.

Very enthusiastic teacher who calls upon students in class by name.  Expects a lot of work on class projects, but his tests are fair.  His first lecture may be scary, but it's worth staying in the class.
Very passionate when teaching, he's a pretty good prof. that makes class interesting
No Comments
No Comments
NOT (Awesome prof who really cares about the well-being of his students. )
Awesome prof who really cares about the well-being of his students.
